newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico bank restructuring cost 9 pct/GDP - B.Stearns.
newsitem.headline: Mexico bank restructuring cost 9 pct/GDP - B.Stearns.

text.p: Bear Stearns estimates that the restructuring of the Mexican banking system will cost the government close to nine percent of the country's gross domestic product by the end of 1996.

"In Mexico, the government estimates the cost of the clean-up at about eight percent (net present value) of 1996 GDP, while we believe it to be closer to nine percent," Bear Stearns said in a special report on Mexican banks written by analysts Alberto Sanchez and Maria Miguelez.
The Mexican government implemented an array of debt relief programs and other measures following the economic crisis precipitated by the December 1994 peso devaluation.
Bear Stearns said the expected economic recovery in Mexico could help lower the cost of restructuring.
"...Good management and, most of all, a strong economic recovery can significantly reduce this cost," the report said.
Bear Stearns looked favorably on the support programs for lending institutions, but called attention to some lessons learned from Chile following its banking crisis.
"Indexing debts to inflation and maintaining them at face value only delays the recognition of losses," the report said.
